text: Bakur II (, Latinized as Bacurius), of the Chosroid Dynasty, was a king of Iberia (natively known as Kartli; ancient Georgia) from 534 to 547. Bakur was the son and successor of King Dachi. According to the medieval Georgian chronicler Juansher, he died leaving young children and Iberia fell under the Sassanid control.Martindale, John Robert (1992), The Prosopography of the Later Roman Empire, p. 169. Cambridge University Press, . He had two children, Pharasmanes V and one of the parents of Pharasmanes VI. ==See also== * Sasanian Iberia ==References== Category:Chosroid kings of Iberia Category:6th- century monarchs in Asia Category:People of the Sasanian Empire of Georgian descent
title: Bacurius II of Iberia
